author: Siobhan Mcfadyen
title: Trade boost for Brexit negotiators as WTO CUTS global tariffs | UK | News | Express.co.uk
text:
GETTY Theresa May will be happy with the news of the new WTO trade rules The agreement will enable more smaller businesses to break out of local and national markets, and tap into regional and international value chains WTO spokesperson Arancha Gonzalez 
A total of 112 of the WTO's 164 members signed up to the agreement which is estimated to add 20 million jobs worldwide, according to the Paris Chamber of Commerce. 
The news is particularly good news for small traders and independent companies whose businesses cannot swallow the cost of current trade regulations therefore strangling business. 
Executive Director of the International Trade CEntre Arancha Gonzalez said: “The (agreement) will enable more (smaller businesses) to break out of local and national markets, and tap into regional and international value chains.” GETTY Theresa May and her cabinet will trigger Article 50 next month 
The news is positive for UK Government Brexit negotiators who are set to face tough talks as the UK tries to exit the European single market. 
The absolute best scenario the British taxpayer can hope for is a Global Free Trade Option which would see the UK offer to remove all tariffs on imports from other nations providing they reciprocate. 
However the Government's Brexit negotiators are also said to be looking at a "super Canada" free trade deal with the EU - who currently impose 700,000 pages of red tape on businesses. GETTY The WTO has implemented new rules that tackle trade barriers 
Canada secured the CETA agreement to eliminate 98 per cent of tariffs despite being only the EU's 12th largest trading partner and with the EU running a small surplus with them. 
Taxpayers are being asked to send £20bn gross to the EU this year alone while the Treasury has committed to sending a further £71bn until 2020. 
And according to the Office of Budget responsibility figures, the UK will only get a rebate of £30bn meaning £61bn will be sent to Europe while Britain tries to negotiate its exit. 
Two weeks ago a legal expert told Express.co.uk that under Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty, Britain has the legal right to leave the EU without a withdrawal agreement should they not agree to exit terms. 
And Prime Minister Theresa May can easily thwart any attempts by EU leaders, including Polish politician Donald Tusk and Luxembourg's former Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker, to hold the British taxpayer to ransom by simply saying no. 
Hedge fund manager Christopher O’Donnell said: "Britain is the sixth largest economy in the world and is no backwater minnow that must comply with the erroneous demands of an overbearing unelected big brother or economically starve. 
“In additional to London being the financial centre of the world, in 2016 the UK had a trade deficit of approximately £68.7bn with the EU. The Best Trade Prospects for the UK Thu, February 16, 2017 Play slideshow 1 of 11 
"If Britain and the EU stop trading with each other, the EU will suffer tremendously more than Britain. 
"Britain has both the legal and commercial muscle to dictate its exit terms to the EU and it would be jolly good if Britain citizens embraced this.” 
Brussels politicians have asked for additional settlement costs of as much as £50bn plus the £91bn total contribution committed over the next three years. Related articles
